message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Marathon 2: A Navigation System
Paper Abstract: Developments in mobile robot navigation have enabled robots to operate in warehouses, retail stores, and on sidewalks around pedestrians. Various navigation solutions have been proposed, though few as widely adopted as ROS Navigation. 10 years on, it is still one of the most popular navigation solutions. Yet, ROS Navigation has failed to keep up with modern trends. We propose the new navigation solution, Navigation2, which builds on the successful legacy of ROS Navigation. Navigation2 uses a behavior tree for navigator task orchestration and employs new methods designed for dynamic environments applicable to a wider variety of modern sensors. It is built on top of ROS2, a secure message passing framework suitable for safety critical applications and program lifecycle management. We present experiments in a campus setting utilizing Navigation2 to operate safely alongside students over a marathon as an extension of the experiment proposed in Eppstein et al. The Navigation2 system is freely available at https://github.com/ros-planning/navigation2 with a rich community and instructions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Behavior tree"

Links: [{"title":"Behavior tree (artificial intelligence, robotics and control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree_(artificial_intelligence,_robotics_and_control)"},{"title":"Behavior tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree"},{"title":"File:Set of Requirements Behavior Trees.jpg","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Set_of_Requirements_Behavior_Trees.jpg"},{"title":"Fall webworm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_tree"},{"title":"Social caterpillars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_caterpillars"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about behavior trees:

## Definition and Purpose

A behavior tree is a mathematical model of plan execution used in computer science, robotics, control systems and video games. There are actually two main meanings of the term:

**In AI and Robotics:**
They describe switchings between a finite set of tasks in a modular fashion.(no content)The approach was extended into a tree-like organization of behaviors, with extensive application in the game industry as a powerful tool to model the behavior of non-player characters (NPCs), and they have been extensively used in high-profile video games such as Halo, Bioshock, and Spore.

**In Systems Engineering:**
A behavior tree is a structured visual modeling technique used in systems engineering and software engineering to represent system behavior, utilizing a hierarchical tree diagram composed of nodes and connectors to illustrate control flow and system actions.

## Advantages

Behavior trees are visually intuitive and easy to design, test, and debug, and provide more modularity, scalability, and reusability than other behavior creation methods.

## Modern Applications

Recent works propose behavior trees as a multi-mission control framework for UAV, complex robots, robotic manipulation, and multi-robot systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Mobile robot navigation"

Links: [{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Distributed architecture for mobile navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_architecture_for_mobile_navigation"},{"title":"Layered costmaps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_costmaps"},{"title":"Autonomous navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_navigation"},{"title":"Davide Scaramuzza - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Davide_Scaramuzza"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about mobile robot navigation:

## Definition and Core Components

Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)In order to navigate in its environment, the robot or any other mobility device requires representation, i.e. a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Types of Mobile Robots

Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location. Mobile robots can be "autonomous" (AMR - autonomous mobile robot) which means they are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.

## Navigation Technologies

Vision-based navigation or optical navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finder and photometric cameras using CCD arrays, to extract the visual features required to the localization in the surrounding environment. Additionally, some robot navigation systems use simultaneous localization and mapping to generate 3D reconstructions of their surroundings.

## Practical Applications

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years. Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

Web search results for query: "Dynamic environment robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Boston Dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Dynamics"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Open Dynamics Engine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Dynamics_Engine"},{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"Inverse dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_dynamics"},{"title":"Oxford Robotics Institute - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_Robotics_Institute"},{"title":"Developmental robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Developmental_robotics"},{"title":"Robotics engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics_engineering"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about dynamic environment robotics:

## Overview

There is an increasing interest in robots that can operate autonomously in a dynamic environment, though a significant percentage of robots in commission today are either human controlled or operate in a static environment.

## Key Challenges

Robots operating in dynamic environments require navigation hardware and software to traverse their environment, and unforeseen events like people and other obstacles that are not stationary can cause problems or collisions.

Autonomous robots remain highly vulnerable to unexpected changes in real-world environments, and even minor variations like a sudden beam of sunlight disrupting vision systems or unanticipated terrain irregularities can cause entire systems to fail.

## Navigation and Sensing

Some highly advanced robots such as ASIMO and Meinü robot have particularly good robot navigation hardware and software. For dynamic areas, such as warehouses full of pallets, AGVs require additional strategies using three-dimensional sensors such as time-of-flight or stereovision cameras.

## Machine Learning Approaches

Reinforcement learning is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal. However, RL agents trained in specific environments often struggle to generalize their learned policies to new, unseen scenarios, which is a major setback preventing the application of RL to dynamic real-world environments where adaptability is crucial.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about dynamic environment robotics:

## Overview

There is an increasing interest in robots that can operate autonomously in a dynamic environment, though a significant percentage of robots in commission today are either human controlled or operate in a static environment.

## Key Challenges

Robots operating in dynamic environments require navigation hardware and software to traverse their environment, and unforeseen events like people and other obstacles that are not stationary can cause problems or collisions.

Autonomous robots remain highly vulnerable to unexpected changes in real-world environments, and even minor variations like a sudden beam of sunlight disrupting vision systems or unanticipated terrain irregularities can cause entire systems to fail.

## Navigation and Sensing

Some highly advanced robots such as ASIMO and Meinü robot have particularly good robot navigation hardware and software. For dynamic areas, such as warehouses full of pallets, AGVs require additional strategies using three-dimensional sensors such as time-of-flight or stereovision cameras.

## Machine Learning Approaches

Reinforcement learning is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal. However, RL agents trained in specific environments often struggle to generalize their learned policies to new, unseen scenarios, which is a major setback preventing the application of RL to dynamic real-world environments where adaptability is crucial.

## ROS Robot Operating System - Search Results

Here's what I found about the Robot Operating System:

### Overview
Robot Operating System (ROS or ros) is an open-source robotics middleware suite. Despite its name, ROS is not an operating system (OS) but a set of software frameworks for robot software development, and it provides services designed for a heterogeneous computer cluster such as hardware abstraction, low-level device control, implementation of commonly used functionality, message-passing between processes, and package management.

### Key Features
Running sets of ROS-based processes are represented in a graph architecture where processing takes place in nodes that may receive, post, and multiplex sensor data, control, state, planning, actuator, and other messages.

### History and Development
The first official Robot Operating System (ROS) distribution was released in May 2010, and quickly gained widespread adoption.(no content)Willow Garage was gradually dissolved in the ensuing years into several spin-offs, including the Open Source Robotics Foundation (OSRF), which was created in May 2012 to continue to shepherd the development of ROS and the Gazebo simulator.(no content)Open Robotics is the primary maintainer of the Robot Operating System, and the Gazebo simulator.

### Licensing and Support
The main ROS client libraries (C++, Python, and Lisp) are released under the terms of the BSD license, and as such are open-source software and free for both commercial and research use.

## Summary

I've successfully extracted and classified entities from the Navigation2 paper. Here's what was completed:

### Paper Classification
**Type:** `contribution` - The paper proposes Navigation2, a new navigation solution that builds on ROS Navigation.

### Extracted Triples (4 entities)

1. **Robot navigation** (task)
   - Relation: `proposes`
   - Wikipedia: [Robot navigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation)
   - Relevance: Navigation2 proposes new methods for robot navigation in dynamic environments and modern sensor systems.

2. **Robot Operating System** (tool)
   - Relation: `uses`
   - Wikipedia: [Robot Operating System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_Operating_System)
   - Relevance: Navigation2 builds on ROS Navigation and is built on top of ROS2, a secure message passing framework for robotics.

3. **Behavior tree (artificial intelligence, robotics and control)** (method)
   - Relation: `proposes`
   - Wikipedia: [Behavior tree](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior_tree_(artificial_intelligence,_robotics_and_control))
   - Relevance: Navigation2 uses behavior trees for navigator task orchestration, a key architectural component of the new system.

4. **Autonomous robot** (task)
   - Relation: `proposes`
   - Wikipedia: [Autonomous robot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot)
   - Relevance: Navigation2 enables robots to operate autonomously in warehouses, retail stores, and alongside pedestrians.

### Validation
✅ **PASSED** - All validation checks completed successfully with 4 triples properly structured and verified.
